Award.AwardTitle: Genetic and Molecular Characterization of Two Quantitative Trait Loci for Circadian Rhythm in Neurospora crassa

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Most eukaryotic organisms display cellular and behavioral rhythms with a period of approximately 24 hours. These rhythms are collectively called the biological or circadian "clock", and this clock influences many of an organism's activities, such as the sleep/wake cycle in humans. Through genetic, biochemical, molecular, and genomic studies, the filamentous fungus Neurospora crassa has served as an excellent model system for unraveling many biological mysteries. Due to the commonality of the core mechanisms of the circadian clock in eukaryotes, understanding the clock in Neurospora should improve our understanding of its functioning and biological consequences in a wide range of organisms. The goal of this project is the molecular characterization of two major quantitative trait loci (QTLs) that contribute to circadian rhythms. The project should provide insights into the biology of both the circadian clock and quantitative trait loci.

This research will be integrated into a new laboratory module for the investigator's "Circadian Rhythms" course. The laboratory module will provide undergraduate students - science majors and non-majors alike - with an opportunity for hands-on experience in the experimental characterization of the fungal circadian clock, along with insights into the nature and study of quantitative traits. This will be an invaluable learning experience for these students, and will help them develop into the intellectually informed, scientifically sophisticated citizens that the nation needs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many living organisms experience predictable changes of daily and seasonal cycles. Therefore having an internal clock is crucial for an organism preparing for incoming environmental changes. When this 24-hour period cellular clock, called the circadian clock, is not working properly in humans, we experience many pathological symptoms including jet-leg, obesity, diabetes, and cancer. Understanding the mechanisms on how organisms generate this information is not only an interesting biological function but also an important knowledge for improving human wellbeing.

Using a quantitative genetics approach, we identified all genetic elements (quantitative trait loci, QTL) involved in clock phenotypes. We used a simple eukaryotic fungal organism, Neurospora crassa, in our study. The organism has the same eukaryotic cell like a human’s, and allows us to do many invasive studies that we cannot perform in humans for ethical reasons. For example, we characterized circadian characteristics of 200 sibling individuals from two parents, and sequenced the genomes of all strains. By statistical analysis, we identified many chromosome regions that are regulating developmental circadian rhythms. To identify and characterize novel clock genes, we crossed the progeny with extreme clock phenotype with the mother (backcross). By repeating this backcross, we created strains contains a small fragment of the father’s chromosome in the background of mother chromosomes with the father’s clock phenotype. In the current study, we focused in one region of chromosome 5, and narrowed down the region of chromosome into a small region that contains 18 predictable genes. None of the predictable genes encoded in this region is known clock gene. Thus, it promises that we will identify a novel clock gene determines time of a day.

In the process of backcrossing, we found an unexpected genetic phenomenon called ‘linkage drag’. This phenomenon is well known in the breeding community. When a breeder tried to integrate one beneficial trait into commercial crops or animals, there could be undesirable traits, such as disease-susceptible phenotype ‘dragged’ into the commercial crops or animals. We found that a region in chromosome 1 is co-segregated with the QTL region in chromosome 5. Since N. crassa is a simple haploid organism with rich genetic and genomic resources, our finding opened an opportunity to characterize the genetic phenomenon that is poorly understood.

The outcome of the current research is shared with the research community through six invited seminars, eight posters in scientific conferences. The funding partially supported publishing two papers so far. One paper reporting all major discoveries from the project is in preparation.

The current project supported 1) creating a highly interactive undergraduate course, Circadian Clock Lab, as proposed in the grant application, 2) partially supported one postdoc, two graduate students, 10 undergraduate students, and two high school students for a research training. Our research facility is located in Camden NJ. Camden School District is recognized as one of the under-privileged communities in the nation. The resources generated in the current project assisted the Rutgers University-Camden campus project ‘Future Scholars’ a multi-year project aimed to encourage Jr./Sr. High school students to pursue the higher education.
